Posts.Content: Oct 25, 2012 06:28PM New-girl wrote: Why no waxing?  I have had my pits waxed for several years prior to my bmx.  My BS was thrilled I was already doing it and just cautioned to have someone who would not burn me.  Never a problem with my person.  I  just got a free laser hair removal session from my PS.  I wasn't impressed so I won't be spending the money to do the remaining 5 sessions but both waxing and laser were perfectly good options presented to me.  I cannot imagine trying to shave especially now with the concave areas under my arms from my bmx.  Also I am missing 16 nodes putting me at high risk.

Posts.Content: Jun 7, 2016 09:01PM New-girl wrote: So now we know how different our skin advice is from the doctors what about the routine for treatment? I go downstairs to what I call the dungeon.  No cell service.  I go into the ladies dressing room where two curtains are stocked with nice folded cotton gowns.  Breast cancer patients close in front, others I have noticed close in back.  Larger sizes are in the closet.  Once you have undressed and put your belongings in a bag they give you the first day, you wait in the room until your name is called.  No drinks or food is allowed in here and there is nothing to read and no tv so we all talk everyday.  We are allowed to keep our shoes on and there are 9 treatments rooms.  There is a monitor that tells you what rooms are running behind and which ones are on schedule.  We always have the same treatment room.  When we are called, we are escorted down the hall to our treatment room.  We give our birthday and they have a picture of us on the monitor.  We go into the room and leave our purses and clothes bag on the chair.  A soft sheet is on the table and most of the time there is no music or above table tv.  Sometimes there is so I am not sure who decides what to have on each day.  Every 6 days we have xrays along with treatment.  Normal day takes about 8 minutes once in the treatment room.  After we are done we go back to the changing room and throw our cotton gown into the dirty laundry bag. Before treatment started I was given a nice folder with a DVD and sheets telling me what to expect.  It had on it the three tech I would have everyday.  Since that time almost 4 weeks ago, each day has been new techs.  Somedays this is no big deal but there is one tech who takes very little time adjusting me and we get in and out very fast.  Today I had all new people who could not get the adjustments correct.  Finally they did but my arms were badly contorted and sore when I left.  Hope my favorite tech is back tomorrow.  Anyone else deal with musical techs everyday? Doctor visits are very inconsistent too.  My doctor barely is in the room before she shoots out.  Never has looked under my arm.  Last week she was gone so I had the one everyone seems to adore.  She examined me and looked at my back, underarm and forearm.  Sat in the room and answered questions.  Wow what a difference.  So again more inconsistencies.  Curious if the Canadian experience is as different as the amount of treatments they give.  Curious also about the shoe thing.  Cleanliness?  And definitely happy to get the cotton gowns.
Posts.Title: Spring 2016 Rads Moderators Sitti

Posts.Content: May 25, 2016 06:31PM New-girl wrote: They wrap my bolus in a sheet and it is actually nice to lay on my chest so I don't feel so exposed.  Over hump day and on Friday I will have finished an entire week!  No issues yet but I am putting expensive body butter on every night as per a friend who said it was wonderful and kept her from having issues with her skin.

Posts.Content: Jun 13, 2016 03:11PM New-girl wrote: Ok finished 17/33 today.  This past weekend my back was really hurting and itching.  I felt bumps but kept thinking I was just imagining it.  So I looked in the mirror and sure enough on my upper back was a clear red area with bumps like I have on my chest.  Probably on my mid to right shoulder area about 6-9 inch radius.  So today I asked the techs and they said that is the exit area of the rads.  Never ever told to expect this or do I remember reading it on the boards.  I would have been including it in my skin routine if I had known.  Has anyone else experienced this?

Posts.Content: Jul 2, 2016 04:09PM New-girl wrote: LTF- This 3 day weekend could not have come fast enough.  Under arm pain and skin is at its worst.  Taking Aleve and an occasional Valium at night to get me comfortable.  I asked the RO if the boosts had anything to do with it and she said no its just the cumulative effects of the 28 treatments finally catching up.  I woke up this morning feeling like someone had shoved hot coals under my arms.  Not fun.  I am hoping I am at the worst and it will start to get better soon.  Skin still intact but super sensitive.  TMI question for the anniversary couples....when do you feel well enough to even think romance?  Even with the gorgeous B&B and my husband I adore, I would be too miserable to even think romance.  How long after treatment ended did the feeling of wanting to be touched come back?

Posts.Content: May 20, 2016 02:58PM New-girl wrote: Today was my 2nd day of zaps of 33.  Nothing major but while in the waiting room the girls and I were all talking and they said most of them didn't like my RO.  One day a week, we all get a quick "physical" from the RO.  Apparently my doctor saw everyone last week cause the other doctor was gone.  Anyway the other women were saying my doctor doesn't do any exam other than a very quick not even close up look.  So today sure enough after waiting 30 min to see the RO she zipped in took a quick look from 2 feet away and said fine and that was it.  If nobody had mentioned it while waiting, I wouldn't have thought anything about it. Can yall tell me how often you see the RO and what is done during that time?
Posts.Title: Spring 2016 Rads Moderators Sitti

Posts.Content: May 28, 2016 03:34PM New-girl wrote: MelancholyL, I just finished my first full week of rads and it has been a very emotional journey.  Didn't really have a meltdown until day 6.  The techs were running behind and not as friendly.  It was raining and the traffic was horrible.  I was tired from getting up early every morning and being reminded everyday I had to go fight cancer.  So I felt miserable all day yesterday.  I am tons better today with a good night sleep and knowing I have a three day break from the routine.  Everyone in the waiting room tells me it flies by and I agree with checking off everyday we finish.  But I also am reading a book by Brene Brown and she has a chapter on self-compassion which I am trying to do.  Think of how you would respond to your child if she were undergoing this treatment.  In other words, be compassionate to yourself during this time.  Don't beat yourself up if you have a hard day dealing with this.  For me its the long drive and disruption to my daily routine that gets me down.  I have never been a go to the doctor person and every single day I have at least one visit to the doctor.  It stinks.  I hate it.  But I accept it and try to look for the blessings and nuggets of joy each day.  Enjoy your long weekend and cheers to finishing your first visits!
Posts.Title: Spring 2016 Rads Moderators Sitti

Posts.Content: Jun 4, 2016 05:02AM New-girl wrote: I just finished my 11/33 today.  Today was also my doctor visit day and I have a dumb question.  What actually does the RO do?  I mean I know she saw me before I started and looked at all my info and made the treatment plan.  She from what I understand, met with the physics guys and figured the rad rays and position and all the technique stuff.  But I never see her except on Fridays and the nurse asks how my skin is doing, and she comes in and asks the same thing and says great and leaves.  Today I had a list of questions like how do you know my body is absorbing the correct amount ( there is no way to know), why is the Canadian protocol shorter ( they are starting to do it here but only for women with breasts intact not mastectomies), and final question was will my skin continue to do well ( she answered yes).  So I gather she would look at me more closely if there was a problem but during the normal week does she have anything to do with my treatment? So far other than getting me started, I am not impressed with the long waits for the appointments just so she can say everything is fine.

Spent two days this week getting marked for boosts which start next Wednesday.  I can see the end and I am so excited but our little waiting room has bonded so much I will miss all my new friends.  I have learned so much from all of them.  Amazing women all linked by this cancer.  Will anyone else miss the people they have gotten to know on this portion of our journey?

Posts.Content: Jun 25, 2016 08:56PM New-girl wrote: My waiting room has 9 seats.  Last week they were packed both times for over an hour.  I finally went and spoke with the building supervisor as some of the woman having to stand were obviously in need of a chair.  I joke they must be running a special on summertime radiation.  So our little group has become very vocal as we talk about everything from our families to our lives in general.  Very little time is spent on the cancer after we get the basics reported.  All but one of us has breast cancer.  Interesting thing is the background of the group is extremely diverse but we all have the best time just yaking like a bunch of hens in a henhouse.  If there is any joy in going to radiation everyday for over 7 weeks, this bunch of warriors I get to sit with every morning is one of them.
Posts.Title: Spring 2016 Rads Moderators Sitti

Posts.Content: Oct 16, 2012 05:29AM New-girl wrote: I found this site months after my BMX and DIEP surgery.  One thing that I have definitely learned is that intense horrible pain is not normal or necessary.  I suffered needlessly because I did not demand pain relief.  This is not childbirth where you get an award for going natural.  This is emotional, stressful and traumatic and physical pain should not be a daily part of this process.  I have learned that some doctors give basically nothing for pain relief ( mine didn't) while others gave plenty.  By my second surgery, I made sure the doctor knew I wasn't planning on hurting.  Some discomfort is expected ( I had no problem with any of my biopsies and other tests) but make sure you get some relief for SNB and afterwards.  Fine if you don't need it but have it in case you do.  Pain does not help the healing process.
Posts.Title: scared how much it is going to hurt Mother4Life curveball

Posts.Content: Aug 24, 2012 01:08PM New-girl wrote: Hi Kitty, You are in an awesome place.  I didn't find this site until well after my surgery and I so wish I had found it before.  What kind of surgery are you having?  I found tons of great info about preparation that would have really helped my recovery.  Spend time if you are comfortable learning everything you can.  Best of wishes and pm if you ever want more information.
Posts.Title: Texas DFW Area Doctor Recommendations kittykoma05 kittykoma05

Posts.Content: Sep 3, 2012 11:54AM New-girl wrote: I would ask to see pictures of his current work.  I was shown lots of pictures which helped me show him what I liked and didn't.  Really helped when I got to Phase II and had to pick out sizes of nipples and areolas.  This was overwhelming at the time but now I am getting used to making my wishes known and not feeling guilty about it.  Speak up.  Also at least in my case, the PS determined all pain meds in the hospital and for recovery.  I wish I had specifically asked him about that.  He was very stingy with pain meds and after getting to know his nurses I now know what I should have demanded from him.  You should not have to endure needless pain.  Ask upfront who will be in charge of your pain management.
Posts.Title: What questions to ask my plastic surgeon? One week to go. Krishelle SpecialK

Posts.Content: Aug 23, 2012 07:52PM New-girl wrote: I went to Dr. Laidley earlier this year.  She is very warm and personable.  Her nurses are awesome.  However pain management at Medical City was poor.  Nuclear Medicine there will not offer any pain meds if you have to have a sentinel node biopsy.  Because of the PTSD I am suffering from that experience, I would choose another hospital and doctor.  Several friends I have met since my experience went to either Big Baylor downtown or Presby and both had better experiences than mine.
Posts.Title: Texas DFW Area Doctor Recommendations kittykoma05 kittykoma05

Posts.Content: Mar 15, 2016 04:57AM New-girl wrote: I had a modified radical mastectomy in 2012. I too went to the "top" team in my area and thought I researched everything. I was told a few cells could be left behind but a bmx was the most aggressive form of treatment I could choose. Because of the course of treatment, I did not have to do radiation or chemo. They did ask my to take tamoxifen which I declined. 2016 I am diagnosed with a recurrence. Have now been to 4 doctors at different hospitals. I am supposedly seeing the top ones again in our area. Saw one last week at a major research hospital. She told me I had excessive tissue left after my bmx!! Said even though I had a modified bmx the surgeon left way too much tissue in the area! She recommends a 2nd mastectomy to remove my DIEP flaps and more breast tissue. I am ticked, mad and frustrated. I had no idea I should have asked to see how much breast tissue was left behind after surgery. BTW, the new MRI I had done in 2016 showed it clearly. Pretty scary stuff when I saw all the tissue with calcifications that matched my mammograms in 2012. Now I realize I should have been doing mammograms every year. Thought it was stupid without real breasts so I didn't ever push getting them done.
Posts.Title: Did u know Breast Tissue can b left behind w/Mastectomy ErskineGirl besa

Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2012 08:33AM New-girl wrote: 1962 was a very good year!  Happy Happy Birthday!  Enjoy the celebration!
Posts.Title: I made it to the big 50!!!! LuAnnH Annie62

Posts.Content: Jun 14, 2012 11:52AM New-girl wrote: Your post brought me to tears.  I am tired of people telling me how "lucky" I am to get new perky boobs.  I am tired and frustrated by my good friends telling me they would be happy to get rid of theirs.  I am angry at people who seem to think losing them is like losing a baby tooth.  I never had big breasts but loved them nevertheless.  They were cute perky and looked good in the 80's.  My college roommates with huge ones would envy my cute bras that did nothing more than dress up my girls.  In the 90's my breasts nursed my babies and brought comfort to them when they were just held next to them.  Lately they were reawakened by my husband and we transitioned to older kids and rekindled romance. I was shocked when my choices to survive depended on allowing them to be removed. Not a simple mastectomy but a radical disforming one.  I am a hoarder at heart and didn't want to get rid of them.  I hated people who tried to make me feel better by glib stupid remarks.  It wasn't like losing my uterus that I no longer needed or wanted.  I would have gladly traded that for my breasts.  I was losing an essential part of my outward apperance and more importantly my love life.  I feel robbed that I didn't get an upgrade.  Although I am told that my PS did an incredible job,but I am left with   two bloobs of uneven flesh thrown on my chest like a slabs of brisket.  Warm to the touch yet missing that incredible sensation of a nipple.  Hideous discs that will somehow be made into nipples that will never become erect on their own or allow me to feel pure pleasure from my husband's touch.  I miss them terribly and hate this disease.  I hate that my husband cannot look at me without getting embarrassed that he is turned off by my apperance.  I miss our lovemaking and worry that we will never recover from this transition from eager lover to wounded mate.  I hope that someday a cure can be found that allows us to keep our breasts. Allows us to deal with this disease without also dealing with our new body.  I miss them and wish I had another choice that would have allowed me to keep them.
Posts.Title: Mourning my breasts pre-mastectomy...A eulogy NanG crystalphm

Posts.Content: Jul 14, 2012 04:54PM New-girl wrote: I am six months out and had the same thing and sometimes still do even now.  I was put on Gabapentin because the drs all thought my pain was just "angry nerves".  I guess at night I noticed it more just trying to get comfortable.  Week 3 was the worst and from then it has gotten so much better.  I still have chest pains but I am not sure now if I am experiencing phantom pains.  All I know is that I still get them from time to time and they wake me up at night.  The Gabapentin have been a lifesaver.
Posts.Title: Chest/Muscle pains after bmx Amy_AZ froggy12

Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2013 06:37PM New-girl wrote: I will tell you my experience about drains.  I had 6 drains after my bmx and diep surgery.  On day five after surgery, the ps told me he was removing the breast drain that had slowed to 15cc per 24 hr. period.  He assured me it would not hurt.  I was already in a great deal of pain at that time since the nurse had not given me my pain meds in over 6 hrs and I had moved quite a bit that afternoon.  The ps yanked the drain out and I almost passed out.  My friend was in the room and saw all color drain from my face.  The ps was embarrassed but of course did not apologize.  Fast forward to 4 days later in his office when I was rested and medicated ( took meds before I went to dr office) and he did it slowly.  Never hurt. Had surgery at NOLA this past December and had to pull my own drains out after a few weeks.  I was talked through the entire procedure and it didn't hurt a bit.  So I think if you stay on top of your pain, and the doctor does it slowly, it should not hurt even a tiny bit.  I think my first drain caught a stitch and pulled and that is what hurt so bad.  They do not stitch up the hole just put a gauze over it.  The only bad scar I have is from the first drain that was pulled. Good luck
Posts.Title: January 2013 Axcillary Lymph Node Dissection (ALND) Surgery Janipani New-girl

Posts.Content: May 17, 2016 10:03AM New-girl wrote: I had my simulation done last Thursday and choose to have the sharpie and tape. They said if they came off I would have to reschedule the simulation thus delaying the start of radiation. Tough I thought I am not getting one more cancer reminder along with radiation. I have showered, bathed and exercised hard ( sweating profusely for one hour) and stickers are still on. I do not scrub them and once I begin going everyday for radiation, the tech said she would touch up anything that faded or came off. Since this is my second go around, I am much more demanding of what I am willing to deal with.

Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2012 03:26PM New-girl wrote: I too declined Tamoxifen.  My MO went through all the positives and negatives and for me the negatives clearly outweighed the positives.  My onco score was 8 so my risk is very low.  I absolutely lost faith in my BS after she failed to be honest with me about my lymph node removal and she strongly got in my face about the Tamoxifen which further made me not do it.  Haven't been back to see her and will just see my MO from here on out.  I did order DIM today and will start taking that.  I am in good health, haven't gotten back to exercising enought, but stay within decent weight ranges.  So I will choose a healthy lifestyle and no SE.  I'm giving my poor body a rest from a traumatic year.

Posts.Title: Why am I still seeing my BS? New-girl J-Bug

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2013 01:56PM New-girl wrote: Hope it is okay to ask you all this question.  I had my bmx and reconstruction almost a year ago.  The highly recommended bs and ps ( they were called the dream team) had huge egos.  I was constantly told how "lucky" I was to have them.  I had a not so good hospital experience due to their lack of pain mangement.  My absolute rage though comes from my bs not telling me she had taken 16 perfectly healthy nodes after suffering through the sentinel node injections.  I thankfully have gone to another facility that has restored some of my faith in the medical profession ( btw my mom is an RN ).  I want to write my bs and ps a letter telling them my disappointment.  I do not seek any revenge but want to treat their other patients better than they did me.  Is this unrealistic that they would even care?  Would I be written off as crazy?  I stopped going to the support group at the hospital because I got so sick of the nurses telling other women how wonderful this team was.  Many thanks for any replies.
Posts.Title: Nurses with Breast Cancer Jo_Ann_K PatRN10

Posts.Content: Dec 24, 2012 08:17PM New-girl wrote: So sorry.  I got my surprise right after New Years of 2012.  I too told nobody including my hubby until I knew what we were dealing with.  You will get through this and this site is a true lifesaver.  The one thing I wish is that I had taken it slower when I got all the information.  I had the best surgeon in the area too but her plan wasn't the best for me.  I discover that too late.  You have time to really look into all your options.  Please breathe and slowly put together what is best for you.  You are the one that will live with the decisions that you make.
Posts.Title: Just Diagnosed- MerryChristmas (sarcastic) smethot Kimberly1965

Posts.Content: Oct 10, 2012 05:56AM New-girl wrote: Found lump and went to gyn on Wednesday.  She immediently sent me for biopsy same morning.  Had numerous mammograms, two needle biopsies and one stereotactic biopsy same day.  Got call the next day, Thursday, from radiologist and told me I had cancer in both breasts.  Was at lunch with my friend.  Radiologist called the breast surgeon and got me in the following Monday.  Cannot believe it happened so fast.
Posts.Title: How did you hear biopsy results--phone or appt? frazzledmom schoolmom

Posts.Content: Apr 21, 2013 07:38PM New-girl wrote: I wish I had found this site and gone directly to NOLA.  Did a year of BMX and DIEP in Dallas and still trying to fix it.  I wanted to get the cancer out quickly but didn't really take into account the long term issues of body image and confidence.  I thought I was making good decisions but I was stressed out to the max and more worried about everyone else and how they were coping.  But hindsight is always easier so I have to quit rethinking my choices.  Best of wishes.
Posts.Title: What I wished I had known.... PeggySull sciencegal

Posts.Content: Oct 13, 2012 04:36PM New-girl wrote: I have 12 nodes out of my right arm and 4 taken from my left.  So I have bp and ns out of left.   Really hate not having a good option.  BP out of my leg was not accurate enough and dr just started taking it from my left arm.  :/
Posts.Title: CALLING ALL STAGE I SISTERS sheila888 MCBaker

Posts.Content: Oct 19, 2012 04:04PM New-girl wrote: I had 16 lymph nodes removed in February this year.  I still have numbness and shooting pains.  It is much less than it was earlier this year but nevertheless a common annoyance.  I take muscle relaxers at bedtime if I am unable to sleep.  I have spoken to women 4 years out that are still having my same symptoms.  Welcome to our new normal.  It does get better as you get used to it I suppose.
Posts.Title: Still in pain 2 weeks after lymph node removal doll0422 Jennie93

Posts.Content: New-girl wrote: I had a complete radical BMX in February with DIEP reconstruction.  For the following 6 weeks after surgery, I saw both my BS and PS every week.  I figured the BS just wanted to make sure the PS did a good job.  Insurance paid it as post surgical visits so no big deal other than the endless time waiting in her very busy waiting room. She never did anything more than look at me and asked how I felt.  I had to push to get PT.  She never told me about the 21 lymph nodes she removed. So now she wants to see me twice a year for goodness knows how long and insurance will make me pay for it.  I asked why I needed to see her and she said to follow up.  For what?  I have no breasts left!  Oh any breast tissue.  So seriously, why does a person ever continue to see the BS?  Dx 1/19/2012, DCIS, <1cm, Stage I, 0/16 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Dx 1/19/2012, ILC, Stage I, Grade 2, 0/16 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Dx 1/19/2012, IDC, 1cm, Stage I, Grade 2, 0/16 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Surgery 2/13/2012 Lymph node removal: Left, Right, Sentinel; Mastectomy: Left, Right; Reconstruction (left): DIEP flap; Reconstruction (right): DIEP flap Surgery 7/26/2012 Reconstruction (left): Nipple reconstruction; Reconstruction (right): Nipple reconstruction Surgery 12/14/2012 Reconstruction (left): DIEP flap, Nipple reconstruction; Reconstruction (right): DIEP flap, Nipple reconstruction Dx 1/19/2016, IDC, Right, <1cm, Stage IA, Grade 1, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Why am I still seeing my BS? New-girl J-Bug

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2013 07:59AM New-girl wrote: The nurses covered so much for the doctors and I tried to be a noncomplaining patient.  I wanted to be liked by my dream team.  I totally get that my nodes may have been in the breast tissue but the first question I asked out of surgery was "how many nodes?".  My husband asked.  It was a huge question because it was almost guaranteed to me that the cancer had spread.  She assured us many times during my week stay in the hospital that it was 3 nodes only.  During the next month when I went every week for post op ( I still do not understand why so many post ops with her) she never ever mentioned the additional nodes.  I finally asked for my pathology report and confronted her PA with it.  She stammered and acted like she had never seen my path report.  I just do not want another woman getting treated the way I was treated.
Posts.Title: Nurses with Breast Cancer Jo_Ann_K PatRN10

Posts.Content: Oct 15, 2012 03:07PM New-girl wrote: I read an article earlier this year about the effects of anesthesia.  It talked about differences in tastebuds, sleep interruption and a host of other things.  Some things changed back some didn't.  I know that I adore mexican food but for the first six weeks after surgery, the smell of it made me sick.  I also do not sweat like I used to but I also had 16 nodes removed.  Have no clue if they means anything but I think our bodies are just put through such trauma that we may never know what is due to the surgery, drugs or just our aging process.
Posts.Title: Did your body chemistry change after surgery? Andrea623 aussie12

Posts.Content: Aug 28, 2012 05:58PM New-girl wrote: You are in shock.  Breathe deep and stay near positive people.  Best advice I got.
Posts.Title: In shock bennymuffins websister

Posts.Content: Jul 21, 2012 04:15PM New-girl wrote: Torriodon...I hope you find strength and peace talking with everyone on this site. I was four months into treatment when I just felt so sad.  I have never had much patience with depressed people .  I always have tried to put things into perspective and find joy in all things.  Cancer completely threw that out the window.  I worried about my 13 year old all the time.  Worried that my depression would scar her forever.  I absolutely had rage towards my ob/gyn who blew me off a year ago when I went in with a inverted nipple.  I felt lonely and abandoned by my husband who couldn't handle my range of emotions.  I found this site and started finding strength in women who were traveling this road with me.  I got into a great support group that let me vent without judging me.  I got a prescription for Valium in case I started crashing into despair.  I only have had to take it once in two months but I like knowing it is there.  I have started to regain my joy for living.  Seeing the positives that have come from all of this.  YES there are some positives from this nightmare.  Start focusing on the good things that are in your life.  But don't beat yourself up when you cannot be strong.  Many hugs.
Posts.Title: I didn't ask for much in life.... Torridon Gitane

Posts.Content: Oct 28, 2012 12:24PM New-girl wrote: Did anyone watch the Friday episode on TLC of Say Yes to the Dress Atlanta?  Lori the shop owner was diagnosed in April of this year with breast cancer.  Showed her finding out , going through a lumpectomy and returning to get a bmx with reconstruction.  I have to say she looked amazing after just one week.  Not sure how much the make up team and hair people at TLC had to do with it but she looked great.
Posts.Title: TV show "Parenthood" shows the breast cancer experience kira Soteria205

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2016 07:45AM New-girl wrote: Please reach out and let people know. Call your church or synagogue. Call the places everyone suggested. There are people in this world that will be the sister you need right now. There are so many volunteer organizations that just need to know you need help.
Posts.Title: MIght Have to Go To Surgery Alone MarcellaPa MarcellaPa

Posts.Content: Jun 4, 2013 09:12AM New-girl wrote: My mom is 80 and I am taking her the the dermotologist this Friday for her shingles.  I have goggled everything I can find.  My mom first got them almost 3 years ago and they are getting progressively worse.  They are now all over her face and neck.  She was given Lyrica ( which is almost the same as Gabapentin) but never took it.  I am desperately looking for a doctor to treat her.  What I have read is that it is much worse with people with weakened immune systems such as people with cancer.  My mom doesn't have cancer that we know of but this is very painful and not much information out there. I will post what her doctor says after our appointment.
Posts.Title: Painfull shingles pls need help zohra zohra

Posts.Content: Jul 6, 2016 01:06PM New-girl wrote: I have been to at least 5 of the "top" doctors in Dallas.  Use the search engine and look at all the reviews of Dallas doctors.  I ended up with Dr. Rao at UTSW and could not be happier.  Hard to get in to see her but definitely worth it.
